>  We’re still assessing what style of pick/ban changes makes the most sense for regular games, given the different circumstances (unfamiliar allies, lack of information about your opposition).

Personally, I'd be happy if regular games used the same format as professional games.

While you might not be able to target ban specific players on the enemy team, you can still adjust to the champions picked by your allies and opponents.

* Has the enemy already picked an ADC?  you probably don't need to ban Vayne or Caitlyn.  

* Allies have pick several CC-oriented champions (i.e. Ashe, Nautilus, Janna) while the enemy doesn't have a jungler/support? Consider banning Olaf and/or Morgana.

If your reading comprehension exceeded that of a first grader, you'd know it was 5 bans per team, for 10 total. They even added a pretty chart to make it clear.

Here's an idea for 10 bans in regular play.

All TEN players ban at once. Here me out, similar to blind pick format just for banning. Each player selects a champion to ban and locks it in to finalize said ban. Any champion could be picked-to-ban until it is finalized, to prevent someone from hovering a champion and changing it last second to not get banned.

Example: A player hovers yasuo during the banning phase. Any other player could select yasuo, until one of those players finalizes yasuo as their ban. Thus blacking-out yasuo for every other player, and forcing anyone who had yasuo selected to pick another ban.)

Once the banning phase ends, simply start draft mode or whatever mode applicable.

Thoughts?

Solo Queue needs to have 4 champs who are banned daily by the client. These were the top 4 bans from the day previous across all elos. Then continue with the standard 6 ban system. This results in 10 bans, automatically removing the obvious 4 who are deemed "must ban" across all play.  I understand that every other day the same 4 might indeed just rotate, because they can't be in the 4 auto ban every day due to not being able to ban them in 6 ban system.  This honestly makes the most sense, with the least amount of effort and change.

{{sticker:zombie-nunu-bummed}} I would 100% use the new client if it didn't lag so much compared to the legacy client. The legacy client might lag when selecting a lobby to join before starting the search, but the new one lags on the launch page, lags when going to the lobby selection, lags when starting the queue, lags when it finds a match, lags when the champ select starts, and lags on picks/bans. I do not have any problems with the new client lagging, and my PC is not the greatest. It cost ~$700 in December of 2015, and that includes about $180 for monitor and Win 10. If you lag, you may try using the "Low Spec Mode" and ticking the "Disable Animation" box. Another issue I have is that sometimes the navigation bar at the top completely dissapears and I can only see the client background image. Also, if my powerline adapter drops out on me for a second and I get disconnected from chat it doesn't ever reconnect, which is somewhat frustrating. Other than that, though, I feel the new client has very few bugs for an early beta version. Also, Runes look flipping beautiful. I would like to have more than some symbol telling my what everything is though, it isn't very clear as to what some things are.

Personally, the main reason I don't use the new client is because:

* It doesn't have item sets implemented yet
* Editing rune and mastery pages feels clunkier
* Friends list and previous conversations always appear when opening the client

I like the idea of 1 ban per player in SoloQ, but I can see how it might add to frustratingly long start times due to Q-dodgers.

What about a change to the Q-dodge system? The further into champ select you get, the longer the penalty. Maybe add a minute for each champ locked in.

Ex: base is 6 minutes (first time), P&B gets to second ban phase (6 champs locked in so far) and last pick dodges because second ban phase removes their champ choice. 12 minute ban (6 base plus 1 for each lock)

Double it for a second offense - same scenario would be 24 minutes the next time (12 base plus 2 for each lock).

This keeps dodgers out of Q longer each time and makes it less likely that someone will want to dodge late into P&B. You'll still have people do it, but it will reduce their impact on the overall Q-times.
